Write R Objects to SOMA

Source: R/write_bioc.R, R/write_soma.R
write_soma_objects.Rd

Various helpers to write R objects to SOMA

Usage

# S3 method for DataFrame
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  df_index = NULL,
  index_column_names = "soma_joinid",
  ...,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

# S3 method for Hits
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  sparse = TRUE,
  type = NULL,
  transpose = FALSE,
  ...,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

# S3 method for character
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  ...,
  key = NULL,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

# S3 method for data.frame
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  df_index = NULL,
  index_column_names = "soma_joinid",
  ...,
  key = NULL,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

# S3 method for matrix
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  sparse = TRUE,
  type = NULL,
  transpose = FALSE,
  ...,
  key = NULL,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

# S3 method for Matrix
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  sparse = TRUE,
  type = NULL,
  transpose = FALSE,
  ...,
  key = NULL,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

# S3 method for TsparseMatrix
write_soma(
  x,
  uri,
  soma_parent,
  type = NULL,
  transpose = FALSE,
  ...,
  key = NULL,
  platform_config = NULL,
  tiledbsoma_ctx = NULL,
  relative = TRUE
)

Arguments

x

An object

uri

URI for resulting SOMA object

soma_parent

The parent collection (eg. a SOMACollection, SOMAExperiment, or SOMAMeasurement)

df_index

The name of the column in x with the index (row names); by default, will automatically add the row names of x to an attribute named “index” to the resulting SOMADataFrame

index_column_names

Names of columns in x to index in the resulting SOMA object

...

Arguments passed to other methods

platform_config

Optional platform configuration

tiledbsoma_ctx

Optional SOMATileDBContext

relative

[Internal use only] Is uri relative or aboslute

sparse

Create a sparse or dense array from x

type

Arrow type for encoding x (eg. arrow::int32()); by default, attempts to determine arrow type with arrow::infer_type()

transpose

Transpose x before writing

key

Optionally register the resulting SOMADataFrame in soma_parent as key; pass NULL to prevent registration to handle manually

Value

The resulting SOMA array or data frame, returned opened for write

Writing Character Arrays

Characters are written out as SOMADataFrames with one attribute: “values”; additionally one bit of array-level metadata is added:

  • “soma_uns_outgest_hint ” with a value of “array_1d ”

Writing Data Frames

Data frames are written out as SOMADataFrames. The following transformations are applied to x:

  • row names are added to a column in x entitled “index”, “_index”, or a random name if either option is already present in x

  • a column “soma_joinid” will be automatically added going from [0, nrow(x) - 1] encoded as 64-bit integers

The array type for each column will be determined by arrow::infer_type(); if any column contains a non-atomic type (excluding factors, complexes,and raws), the code will error out

Writing Dense Matrices

Dense matrices are written as two-dimensional dense arrays. The overall shape of the array is determined by dim(x) and the type of the array is determined by type or arrow::infer_type(x)

Writing Sparse Matrices

Sparse matrices are written out as two-dimensional TileDB sparse arrays in COO format:

  • the row indices (“i”) are written out as “soma_dim_0”

  • the column indices (“j”) are written out as “soma_dim_1”

  • the non-zero values (“x”) are written out as “soma_data”

The array type is determined by type, or arrow::infer_type(slot(x, "x"))
